An infant is a child in the earliest period of life up to 12 months of age, while a neonate is a newborn infant who is less than four weeks old . For many years, procedural pain and distress in both neonates during the first 28 days of their lives and older infants (up to one year of life) have been under-studied and under-treated . Several reasons have been proposed for this, such as a belief that neonates and infants do not fully experience pain as adults do (Derbyshire 1999), concern regarding the risks associated with using analgesics and the inability of infants to verbalise their pain. Recent evidence suggests that neonates and older infants do feel pain . Increasing attention has been directed towards pain and distressreducing strategies during painful procedures such as immunisations because of possible short-and long-term adverse effects. We sought to compare the effectiveness of additive pain interventions administered consistently during vaccine injections in the first year of life. We conducted a multicentre, longitudinal, double-blind, add-on, randomized controlled trial. Healthy infants were randomly assigned to 1 of 4 levels of pain management for all vaccine injections at 2, 4, 6 and 12 months: (i) placebo control; (ii) parent-directed video education about infant soothing; (iii) the video plus sucrose administered orally or (iv) the video plus sucrose plus liposomal lidocaine applied topically. All infants benefit from injection techniques that minimize pain.
